thread.title: No. 4 Michigan State beats No. 14 Michigan in shocking fashion
thread.title_full: No. 4 Michigan State beats No. 14 Michigan in shocking fashion

title: No. 4 Michigan State beats No. 14 Michigan in shocking fashion
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest No. 4 Michigan State beats No. 14 Michigan in shocking fashion Jalen Watts-Jackson returns a fumbled punt snap for a touchdown and No. 4 Michigan State takes the only lead that matters in a stunning finish in Ann Arbor Post to Facebook No. 4 Michigan State beats No. 14 Michigan in shocking fashion Jalen Watts-Jackson returns a fumbled punt snap for a touchdown and No. 4 Michigan State takes the only lead that matters in a stunning finish in Ann Arbor Check out this story on courier-journal.com: http://usat.ly/1ROR6yR Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 6 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs No. 4 Michigan State beats No. 14 Michigan in shocking fashion Dan Wolken , USA TODAY Sports 9:14 p.m. EDT October 17, 2015 Jalen Watts-Jackson (20) dives into the end zone for the game-winning touchdown. (Photo: Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports) 123 CONNECT 215 TWEET 2 LINKEDIN 6 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Breaking down No. 4 Michigan State's 27-23 last-second comback at No. 14 Michigan on Saturday: 
THE BIG PICTURE: It would be almost impossible for the fortunes of two seasons to swing more dramatically on one fluke play. 
But in the Big House, Michigan State and Michigan will put their names right up along side Stanford-Cal with the band on the field and the 2013 Iron Bowl. 
With Michigan needing to do no more than get off a punt with 10 seconds left and then defend one play to wrap up a 23-21 win, disaster struck. Punter Blake O’Neill dropped the snap — nobody was even back to field it for the Spartans — and got swarmed by a mess of defenders. The ball landed in the arms of Spartans safety Jalen Watts-Jackson, who outran Michigan’s pursuing defenders, getting to the corner of the end zone before he was cut off and forced out of bounds. He got in as time expired to crush a Wolverines team that was seconds away from entering the national championship conversation. 
Instead, Michigan State is now 7-0, 3-0 in the Big Ten — somehow, some way — despite never leading Saturday until the final horn. The Spartans have fought injury haven’t been impressive all season but keep finding ways to win. The crazy final play will overshadow a great performance by the Michigan defense, which held Connor Cook to 18-of-39 passing for 328 yards. It also appeared to win the game with 1:47 left, forcing three consecutive incompletions and sacking Cook when the Spartans were on the edge of field goal range. 
Michigan State has won seven of the past eight meetings with the Wolverines, unprecedented in the series. 
Michigan running back De'Veon Smith (4) gains ground in the first half vs. Michigan State. (Photo: Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports) 
WHAT WE'LL BE TALKING ABOUT: Besides the final play? Officiating. It was, well, interesting and noticeable at all times — and both sides could have easily left Michigan Stadium game claiming the opposition got some key help from the guys in stripes. 
All told, there were 13 flags (eight on Michigan) and eight instant replay reviews, some of which were on brutally close calls. 
But among the most controversial was the targeting penalty assessed to Michigan linebacker Joe Bolden going head-first into Cook after a slide, disqualifying Bolden from the game and setting up Michigan’s first touchdown. Even though the replay booth upheld the call, Bolden appeared to be shoved into Cook, which made the penalty seem questionable. Follow the road to the 2015 College Football Playoff at The Football Four , our home to rate and debate the nation's best. 
THE DECIDING PLAY: Michigan (5-2, 2-1 Big Ten) is not the kind of team you want to fall two scores behind. Which made it all the more baffling why Spartans coach Mark Dantonio, in a 10-7 game, called a fake punt with 12:01 left in the third quarter on their own side of the field. It’s unclear what the play was supposed to be; it appeared punter Tyler O’Connor was supposed to pass, but he ended up running for the first-down marker. 
O’Connor fell a yard short, giving Michigan — which wasn’t getting much done offensively — a short field at the 38-yard line. The Wolverines cashed in, using safety Jabrill Peppers on offense to break a 28-yard run that set up the touchdown and a 17-7 lead. Michigan beat my statue, but they couldn't beat the MSU Football team! Lol #GoGreen #GoWhite — Earvin Magic Johnson (@MagicJohnson) October 18, 2015 
KEY STAT: Michigan has given up just two plays all year long of more than 30 yards. But with 9:11 left and Michigan State’s season on the line, trailing 23-14, Cook faked two handoffs and found fullback Trevon Pendleton on the wheel route. He was all alone, rumbling 75 yards before being stopped short of the goal-line. It was a nifty and timely playcall with the game slipping away from the Spartans, allowing them to pull within 23-21. 
HOW THE TOP 25 FARED IN WEEK 7 No. 2 Baylor 62, West Virginia 38. Jerome Miron, USA TODAY Sports No. 4 Michigan State 27, No. 14 Michigan 23. Rick Osentoski, USA TODAY Sports No. 8 Florida State 41, Louisville, 21. Mark Wallheiser, AP No. 9 Alabama 41, No. 10 Texas A&M 23. Troy Taormina, USA TODAY Sports No. 22 Memphis 37, No. 12 Mississippi 24. Justin Ford, USA TODAY Sports No. 16 Stanford 56, No. 18 UCLA 35. Kirby Lee, USA TODAY Sports No. 17 Iowa 40, No. 21 Northwestern 10. Jerry Lai, USA TODAY Sports No. 19 Oklahoma 55, Kansas State 0. Scott Sewell, Scott Sewell-USA TODAY Sports Utah State 52, No. 20 Boise State, 26. Rob Gray, USA TODAY Sports No. 25 Toledo 63, Eastern Michigan 20. Tim Fuller, USA TODAY Sports Like this topic?
